title: Large Scale Visual Recommendations from Street Fashion Images
segmentation: So I'm vicknesh from eBay research labs and I'll be talking about large scale visual recommendations from street fashion images and this is joint work with Robinson Pyramid to honor of birth, watch Brady and Meals from the race and all from eBay research.
Then we get started with an example.
Assume you're walking on the street and you like a pair of jeans.
Somebody is wearing an obvious question that you can ask from an E Commerce website or an online shopping.
Website is find me similar items or pants or jeans that look similar to whatever you upload it.
So that question was addressed by us last year at KDD and that is a classic problem of similarity search through images.
This year we're slightly changing the problem statement where we ask the question given your uploading a fashion apparel.
In this case a pant.
Can eBay recommend tops or any other fashion apparel that would go well with the query.
So in this case if you upload a pant, can eBay recommend tops that would go well with it?
And how do we learn this notion of what fashion apparel go well with one another?
We we harvest large scale image datasets from the web and we mind Co occurrence patterns from these datasets to learn a recommender and I'll touch upon these points as we move along.

An one caveat here, since men's clothing and women's clothing are inherently very different, I'll be using women's clothing as a running example through the talk so all the men in the room please excuse me and who?
Come on, let's take a step back.
I'm sure most of the audience or online shoppers.
And let's assume that you're in the middle of your shopping session and you have 1/2 filled shopping cart as shown on the left where the shopper is bartop clothing.
See a top and high heeled shoe and these are shown by the nodes on the right.
The Gray colored nodes where those two variables are clamped and we want to see if we could offer the user a targeted and rich browsing experience of products that are very related.

But they don't think about in this case, they've already brought her in the process of purchasing atop an issue, and we want to see if we could learn a model that could start generating data for glasses, pants or handbags, or which other fashion apparel that would go well with what the user is about to purchase.
And I must clarify here that there are commercial merchandising systems on ecommerce websites that do precisely this, but they use purchase history data or user behavior data.
So you must have seen users who bought this item also bought this other item.
So those are all obtained by parsing query logs or just parsing user behavior data.
But the modality that we use here is purely image base.
We don't use any other extra side information.
So we just try to use images to learn a recommenders, and we hypothesize that Fusion of these two different approaches will.
Lead to a better model moving forward.
So I just want to summarize what I've stated till now.
A similarity search problem is you take a picture which is a query, you upload it to eBay.
You do a similarity search which is basically an inner product or feature vectors and you get a rank list as the output.

So the problem that we are addressing here is coordination search where you upload an input query, let's say an image of apparent and there is a query mapper and this query mapper is what transforms the input feature vector for apparent into something.
For example a top that would go well with the paint and then you again pass it through the similarity search.
And the main part of this work address is how to design this query mapping module.
And as you all may agree with me, fashion is an inherently personal choice, and fashion choices vary a lot from one person to the other.

But there are always a few people who are fashion experts who started trend, and then it catches on or spreads like wildfire and shown on the screen or some images from our data set which were created by fashion experts.
And though these are not color combinations or clothing patterns that we would wear on a daily basis, I'm sure you would not be afraid to give it a try.

The same thing cannot be said about clothing combinations like these, because these may be way too adventurous for people to get started with or to walk on the street and these form negative samples, but these are much harder to get, so we just have a lot of positive samples in between generative models to perform the recommendation.
And so we turn to large scale image datasets created by fashion experts.
And what are the types of image datasets that these fashion experts create?
One could be St fashion data where fashionistas or ordinary people like you and me have a keen sense of interest in fashion.
Start uploading a lot of images on a daily basis of themselves or their friends to the web and that type of data is called.
Street fashion data.

There are fashion experts who constantly keep dressing up celebrities so there is a lot of celebrity data out there and there could be another source for doing celebrity style transfer or there are fashion shows, London, Paris or New York Fashion weeks and there's a lot of YouTube or other videos that can be parsed and recommended from.
Obviously there is also social network data.
But in this work to keep our discussion focused, will focus on the street fashion datasets and the data that we have is like what I've shown here.
They're pretty high resolution images and they come with XY coordinates of tags saying where the apparel that a person is marking is.
For example, if you take point, it doesn't work OK. For example, this image here the user is marked that there is a black colored top at a certain XY location.
There's a zebra colored skirt and red colored shoe.
So the user is marked this information.
Which forms that it's training data for us.
And what happens in the learning phase?

So as you can see what I'm showing here is just a single image from a training data set of, say 100,000 two 100,000 images and let's focus on three apparel, which is top clothing denoted by the red box.
The bottom clothing denoted by the green box and the shoe denoted by the blue box.
And since we know the XY coordinates of where these three apparel are from a training data, we just crop small image patches around each of these coordinates.
And let's assume that each of these apparel.
The visual features that we extract from these apparel are denoted by random variables A1 for the top clothing A2 for the bottom clothing, and a three for the shoes.
So each time you get an image, you're going to fill up a row of the matrix with these three random variables.
And if you just keep repeating the same process over here in training set, you're going to get a huge training matrix.
Where the number of rows corresponds to the number of images in your data and the number of columns correspond to your visual descriptor dimensionality per image.
And as you might all have thought of, this is reducing the problem to standard collaborative filtering type.
Formulation and there are umpteen methods in standard Mail and data mining which solves similar problems and we adopt them too.

To get a solution, but the essence of the learning problem is to learn a joint distribution which is the joint probability of the three random variables A1A two and a three is just cooccurrence estimation.
And this is the learning phase.
And during the test scenario, let's say shopper comes on to eBay and they have bought this card and so this becomes the query for the algorithm and what the algorithm is tasked with this.
Now you have this query try to map it to a query of a top that would go well with this card and then pass it through a similarity search engine which retrieves related items.
And this is basically the results that the algorithm generates.

But mathematically, if you want to look at it, we're fixing a variable which is the bottom clothing or the skirt in this case and condition on a variable being fixed, we want to maximize for a one, which is the query for the feature descriptor for the top clothing, and this is Now a one star, which is the solution of this inference problem.
It becomes a new query and it's passed through a search engine for visual search engine for retrieval.
And though I have sort of just summarize the basic intuition again, what I'm plotting here is a Co occurrence matrix where the.

Y axis corresponds to the different colors that are there in the top clothing in the data set, the X axis correspond to the different colors of the bottom clothing in the data set, and this is just a joint probability distribution or an empirical Co occurrence matrix and the red spots here corresponds to color combinations that occur very frequently in the data set and the blue spots correspond to rare combinations.

And let's assume that the user is coming in and they bought a top clothing and once they get a top clothing, they're basically locking the row, and once the role has been logged, we just looking at the row on the right and this is the conditional distribution of all the bottom clothing.

Given that op clothing color has been selected and this is a conditional distribution which we can sample from an once we sample this week and get it set of new queries or new transform queries that can be used for search.
And not get into the details of the algorithms that we used to implement them.

But broadly speaking, we come up with two classes of algorithms, namely deterministic fashion recommenders and the stochastic ones, and these algorithms range from naive nearest neighbor methods to more sophisticated topic models and such.
And.
Moving on, I'll briefly touch upon the subjective evaluation that we carried out.
As you can imagine, this is a retrieval problem over a large database of images, and getting a ranked list or dense ground truth is challenging problem.

So what we did was we used human subjects for evaluation, which in this case was you have a query as shown on the left, which is a skirt, and as I mentioned, we have five different algorithms that solve the problem.
We wanted to benchmark them thoroughly.

And we show the query and the results of the five algorithms in randomized order to offset the bias in evaluation and the users were or the human subjects were requested to rate the retrievals of each algorithm on a scale from zero through 3.
Zero means I really don't like this.
You're doing something wrong.
3 means really like it, and the continuum in between.
And we use standard evaluation protocols.
That paper that typically used in the research literature and we filtered out results where there was a huge variance in ratings between subjects.
And this plot shows the evaluation of the different algorithms that we had experimented with with the take home message.
There is a lot of information here, but the take home messages we had two types of queries.
One is solid color clothing and the other is patterned clothing.

And for the solid colored clothing, the deterministic recommenders did extremely well, but for the pattern once the stochastic ones tend to perform better and in order to merge these two results together, we train the classifier which could classify whether the incoming query was a pattern or a solid, and then we fused.
We just do a switching.
To pick the recommended that does well for a particular query and that gives the best results.
Moving on, we also looked at the performance of solid versus pattern queries and we got some fashion insights.
One thing that the human subjects never liked was if you recommend something.
There is a pattern for an input pattern query.
They don't like it and they absolutely hate that color combination.
That's something that came out of this study and it is a wake up call for us.
For example, no one likes to wear a striped pattern stripe shirt with stripes, kirtana straight striped top.
So those are some things that can be incorporated to hopefully improve the recommendations overtime.
And because patterns are inherently, they have a lot of variance, solid colors.

You can say that they are only finite amount of solid colors, but patterns the space of patterns is typically a very huge, so getting patterns right is a difficult problem and we feel there's a lot of scope for improving recommendations or retrievals for the pattern queries.
And we wanted to take a little deeper look into patterns.
So we classified patterns into two types, simple patterns and complex ones and simple patterns are ones that have clear structure.
For example, if you have stripes or polka dots, but you have a single theme that's keeping this copied over the entire design, those are simple patterns.
But basically animal print are examples of more complex patterns.
There's no surprises here.
The complex patterns are the ones that are much harder to get, and part of the reason for this is the visual descriptors that we use for.
Capturing the types of patterns are not very robust and there needs to be improvement in computer vision algorithms too for that.
And I'll just conclude with a few.
Take home messages in a summary.
We proposed techniques for data driven visual recommendation.
The key idea was to learn it in a data driven way by using or leveraging large scale visual datasets on the web.

The subjective experiments that we presented validate the capability of the different algorithms and examples scope for improving the work primarily on fashion parsing and using the more recent deep learning features.
We used color for the all this work, but if you use the recent convolution neural network features.
The results we're getting are way better than what we have presented here, so I'll thank you on that note for your patience and attention.
Thanks a lot.
